text: So the tape is on, and so everything is recorded for posterity. Okay, turn the tape off just a second. It is on now, so it is on now. So I'll start off by asking you a little bit about your background, specifically how you grew up and what might have influenced you to write and why science fiction particularly. Okay. Okay. I grew up in a very literary family with an influence on technology. My father restructured the Boeing paperwork stuff at Otis Air Force Base when we had missiles up here in the 50s. So there was a lot of military people around my house and high tech people, pilots, submarine guys, stuff like that. So I met a lot of people like this very early on. and when I was seven, I started reading science fiction, but before that, my mother was a master's in education, my father went to Harvard, and my bedtime story is when I was three and four, well, I'm a fairy queen. So I had a, in mythology, so I had a real good background in not only literature, but in particular sorts of literature that ended up translating into science fiction and fantasy later on. I read fiction voraciously. I got a hardcover book a week with my allowance when I was in second and third grade. Being an over-advantaged child in a public school was very difficult for gifted children. I had really nothing to do in school. I was finished with the year's reading in October, and I would sit. They would make me just sit there. So I did a lot of extracurricular reading. I think the first story I read was James Blish's Surface Pension, and I've now dated myself. I think it was an IF magazine way way back and I read science fiction almost exclusively until I started reading non-fiction of philosophy about 10 and 11 and then at the same time I went through the five libraries within driving distances collection of mythology so I had all the myths of all available countries including Asian and African by then then went into philosophy and work backwards from the existentialists and Sardin back, bounced all the way back to pre-Socratic thought and got into physics from there. And that got me back to hard science through the interaction, really, of philosophy and theoretical physics in the space-time thing and later into geopronometry, which is an area which I really like to play with. And some of that I think shows in the book. When in my late 20s I got involved with a physicist who because he was doing some work in quantum mechanics was interested to see if indeed he could come up with some reversibility. Some evidence that the arrows of time do go both ways. There should be, if indeed this is true, on some level. even though your watch won't put itself together after it's broken on the floor, fly up and land on your wrist. There should be some way that we can determine that time is indeed working both ways. It's an iteration in math. To do that, I punched a lot of buttons because, I mean, I have car dreams, dreams that come true. It's really unfortunate for somebody as logical as I am to be slapped in the face with precognitive dreams and incidences of ESP. So then I went into studying that a little bit. And we did a bunch of computer work, really, testing against probability to see if indeed mine could be demonstrated to be affecting probability in a randomly generated sequence of numbers. And after about a year working on that, we proved our satisfaction that something was happening, and it seemed to be happening most strongly and most consistently in people who were in some way or form connected with nonverbal arts. Musicians, artists, people who paint as opposed to all sorts of artists. But people who are not logically tied down in some way to semantics. Later on, we went and tried, on the basis of that, research to get a National Science Foundation grant to study it. But it was right about the time they were trying to throw the parapsychologist out of the National Science Foundation. Consequently, we did not get the grant and didn't carry it on any further. Does that answer your question? That's a good start. Okay. You have this remarkable background then in reading all sorts of philosophy and that sort of thing and you are interested in science. Are you a logical kind of left hemisphere person? Yeah, most determinedly. The other stuff bothers me very much. Because I like to be able to figure things out, and because most things fall to logic in the end, the things that are illogical tend to be what I concentrate on. Because after one solves what's solvable, what remains the question? The things that one can't determine. And that throws you back to the nature, really, of time and what consciousness is. the role of the observer in not only the modern world, but maybe in the actual creation of what we see as the rational and physical world around us. So that's what I'm working with, struggling to deal with, maybe, in the fiction. Okay. This is, as an aside, but as I mentioned on the phone the other night, I make my living as a scientist, but as a layman, I'm very interested in cosmology and quantum mechanics and that sort of thing. So I think that's probably why your writing appeals to me so much because you investigate some of these things that I can't verbalize nearly as well as another site is a book that you might be familiar with From Being to Becoming by Ilya Prigogini I think you pronounce it yes that's how you pronounce it he's one of my heroes have you seen that book I have seen the book I do not have a copy of it his area is really your area chemistry and thermodynamics and he's dealing in that book with the kind of questions that also interests you, I think it would be nice for you to take a look at. Okay, I appreciate the suggestion. He won the Nobel in, I think, 77, yeah. Plus he comes to Austin. He's part-time at UT Austin, too, so it's not that far away. In it, he's really coming to terms with the same kinds of problems. I mean, are there determinable instances? Is it one flow of time? Why, indeed, isn't this happening? Why don't we see reversibility in nature? And almost calling for a restructure of the questions, which is nice. Very bright, very bright, darn. Oh, yeah, of course. His main bag is non-equilibrium thermodynamics, where you get, oh, I guess there's a big argument that the creationists can throw up that life cannot have evolved spontaneously because entropy makes it go the other way. you tend towards disorder, and he has refuted that quite nicely. I've read quite a few of those papers. So, okay, I guess I ought to stick to them. Let's see. Well, part of my kick in this is this kind of stuff. Of course, the author on the other end might not want to stay forever, so. I don't mind it. Wheeler, too, you would like. Oh, yeah, I'm very familiar. I've read a lot of his stuff. I really like that. The universe ordered itself as it did in the initial instance in order to produce physicists. I think it's just wonderful. Yeah. Let's see, who is it? The anthropomorphic principle. Prophecy principle, right. Yeah, right. That's quite interesting. And then the many worlds. One more clue, let's see. The DeWitt model, it's called the many worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics. It's quite interesting. You are probably familiar with it. Yeah, I was thinking of fooling around with that next time. It's just awful hard to use a structure like that in a book because it's going to not look like a novel. It's going to look like lots of parts of a novel. Right, especially since quantum mechanics says that the many worlds could not communicate amongst each other, but maybe you can find a way to get around that, and then it would be quite interesting. We would be writing really parallel structures, but it would be fun to do. That's what I think science fiction should do, is deal with the new concepts rather than just older, rehashed science fictional concepts because the really creative stuff is starting to happen now because people are asking much more interesting questions than scientists' level. In the Patchen Review article, the second one where you signed your name, you talked about scientific speculation and that perhaps it's not... that even the science fiction writers have grown conservative about speculating about science. That was written a couple of years ago. I guess, do you still feel pretty strongly about that? Yeah, I'm afraid that I do. Because if not, because of the way I work and the amount of concentration and area it takes, I mean, right now, I just got finished with mycotoxins and the whole Afghanistan thing, biochemical warfare, and surveillance stuff. So I've been reading, that's what I've been reading for the last year, really the technology that is here now in depth. So if somebody, what happens is the fiction reading stuff is what I don't get to read when I'm researching a subject is what other people are writing because it's so peripheral to what I'm doing. So if somebody in the last couple years has come along in science fiction who's taking risks and taking shots and using the new data that's coming in, then I don't know about it. But, as of two years ago, when I was really conversant with who was writing and what they were writing, it seemed to me that they were almost ignorant of anything that one would consider an advance in the theory of science that had happened in the last 20 years. And I think that's really a shame because that's what science fiction is supposed to do. We have a brighter audience. They're at an age where they're deciding what they're going to do a lot of the time for a living. They're comfortable with technology and they're adventurous. And to not give a questioning mind something interesting to chew on, which is what I found was nice about science fiction when I first started reading it, is a shame. To some extent, the problem is in the editor's publishers, but they can't buy a better book than you send them. So if people are sending them garbage, which then garbage is all they can buy. I mean garbage from a conceptual point of view, there's plenty of people in science fiction that can write, but there's very few of them that are writing about anything interesting. And what I try to do always is to put in, if not leading edge stuff, new stuff, make the hard stuff simple, at least science that is still viable as a speculation. I really like Twisters. I just love Ken Rose and the whole Twister Theory thing. That makes great sense to me. And I wanted to give people some exposure to it. But there's always a new thought. There's a new permutation. Something more interesting. I was complaining in that about tachyons, because I think tachyons are a dead issue. And considering, especially the source, that the writer, who is certainly aware of more modern and interesting concepts than tachyons, could have done better. And if the best of the writers that we have, in the sense of the most technologically literate, aren't going to do it, then nobody's going to do it and the level will go down and down, as it's been going down in all fiction. It's a conservative market. They want to buy what they can sell. They're absolutely sure that everybody that buys these books is eight years old, and I know that they're not. So I write for my ideal audience, which is intelligent and adventurous. okay I think what I'm going to do now okay I'll go back up to and we'll start on Solistra this is yes oh yes great I keep debating if I start backwards because I had a question that's in from cruiser dreams that has the same thing to do with that but man let's I'll go I'll do it chronologically it'll be easier okay reportedly or it says in the back of the first Solistra book that you had written one short story before you wrote The High Couch of Solistra. So how did you go from writing one short story to a very successful science fantasy novel? Okay. Actually, I didn't even write it beforehand. I wrote this tiny short story called An Antidreaming, and I wrote it between, I guess, between Wind from the Abyss and the Golden Sword just to peg the idea and open the door so I can get back into that thing that I saw. I tend to see a story, the concepts are one thing. You put the concepts in and they gestate, and then I don't have to look around for a story. I mean, I see characters. I don't sit down there to write until I see something. And it's almost like you're looking into a telescope and the story is at the other end, so there's a degree of automatic writing in it. But I always knew I was going to write. you know you win a poetry contest in first grade and you always get an A on the essay question there are certain signs I don't think you can learn to write I think you're either a writer or you're not you can learn to be an author someone who writes just enough to be able to go around and talk about their books and be a big shot or a literary snob but a person who likes is willing to sit in a room and spend most of their time in a non-existent world and make very good friends with a typewriter or a word processor That's something that you have to be born with the drive and the obsession to do. I did a lot of life research before I sat down to write anything because I felt that you have to have something to say. And having survived my research, when we moved to a quiet place and I actually had the time and I found that I did have a specific idea, I sat down and wrote to Lister And I didn't do any warm-up. That is the first thing I ever wrote for sale. And it's also the first draft of the first thing I ever wrote. It never occurred to me that a story could go any way but the original way. So I wrote it and I typed it up and it sat around for a year because I didn't know where to send it. And then I sent it out. And the agent said, well, you know, he thought he could sell it. And I said, fine, because I wrote two more in the meantime. And indeed he did sell them. So I did no warm-up. But I did wait. I didn't try until I knew I could do it. not a big one for preparation. The only preparation I think you can do for writing is reading. And over the years I've done plenty of reading, but the other thing you should need to do if you're going to write about the stuff of life, the human element is to experience some of the human element. And I spent quite a bit of time in New York and underground and doing dangerous, dicey things. And every time something would be exceedingly difficult, like when I was looking down the wrong end of the gun or tied up in my apartment in New York by a hostile forest, I would think, well, I can use this in my book. And it got me through a lot of very difficult situations, just thinking that if I could just get through this, eventually I was going to have plenty of material for a book. And what I ended up doing was writing for a living. you uh wrote using a first person point of view except for a couple of delcretz sequences in the carnelian throne and it's kind of hard to write first person how did you decide to do that i think it was in that case it was easier but with phyllistha um there's a one has to be a little bit messianic to do a book like that i really was concerned that when I got into the very abstract stuff that I must have some way to take them with me. I wanted them to experience this stuff as closely and as possible because of the kinds of things that I was talking about, both the philosophical things and the genetic experience that I wanted to give them. The sufficient characters are almost like walking genes. At the time I was quite taken with Edmund Wilson in sociobiology. I still think some of the things that are valid although they've spun it out past the point where I can agree with them now. So first person was the way to go with that book. As I said I see a story. I don't have to manufacture the story. Once I have a character or a group of characters I can just let it go. By then the work is done and I just write it and I write it in deep immersion and stay home a lot and don't cook dinner. The cats scream at me. So first-person for that was easier to get you really inside the characters and prepared for things like the multiple world stuff that came at the end of that first book later on. And it was a little bit more of a discipline to write first-person because one doesn't do it in essay class, certainly not in college. It just was the way that book wanted to be written. I don't tend to pay too much attention to the style that I'm writing because I want to make the style fit the piece. So the style develops itself in accordance with the concepts that I want to work with. Sometimes I'll get a very dense style like in Earth Dreams was dense. because the concepts were difficult. I knew where I was going to deal with those concepts. I needed a style where when I started talking, technically, it wouldn't be too great a jerk, too different from the stuff that was going on before it. Also, there I was trying to blend the pure logic of hard science with the absolute other side of the brain, ill logic of magic, and I needed a way to do it. So the styles develop out of that. And each group of things I do tends to be very different stylistically from the last. Solicitor is very different from the carrying stuff, which is very different from the sanctuary stuff, which is different. I did a historical with Cal Watkins at Harvard and a Hittite king, which I sold and then reverted him in the process of selling again. And in that book, we had translated stuff that had never been seen in English before, Acadian, and lots of old Hittite. And that style was determined by the fact that I knew I was going to be using big chunks of text and I wanted to use it as it transliterated rather than modernizing the translation. So that again was first person because all the text we had was first person. So I let the story determine the style rather. I don't really choose it. A lot of times I don't think I choose the stories either. When I'm on the rebound from the amount of hard mathematical homework that I do, I tell myself if the story takes me because otherwise why should I have to work so hard? Okay. The set, the Solicitor, The Planet, it's exceedingly complex. You've got all these relationships, you've got all these politics, inter-world politics, intra-world politics, you've got a lot of jargon, at the end you have a dictionary. Leigh Killough said when she writes books, she writes a world book, just describing everything about the world which is often longer than the novel that she writes from it. Did you lay down this world in your head and think it through, or did this just come to you as you were writing it, because it's so damn complex? Okay, I have a very good memory, an edific memory. I can remember everything that I do. And I can also remember most of what I read, you know, page number and how it looks on the page. the glossary and the dictionary and the end paper matter all that stuff was done after high touch was sold at the publisher's request i didn't have that in the original manuscript at all what i had and what i always have is um a manila folder that i keep the manuscript in and where i jot down notes as to what i have done so in other words as i as i made up the words the language i'd write down the new words on the manila envelope i don't like to take a lot of notes because i'll lose them and i just keep it all in my head and i better be damn sure that i remember what's in there so i'm very careful about that but no i don't do anything like that as i tell you it's a very the actual writing for me is a very visceral experience so much as something you know sometimes under your pseudonym i do uh and now time stuff you know hear stuff's in there i mean if i have to stop to get an air and a sectional you know an air map of a particular place to find out what the route would be then that'll pull me out of it or you know how much it costs a particular hotel or what kind of ammunition would be right for this gun or that gun then i have to stop and go and get the data but where it's all made up all i have to do is be consistent with myself and logical within the frame so i keep it in my head where it belongs That way I find if I write a lot of stuff first, then I find that I'm in danger of not explaining it well enough to the reader because I already know it so well that I might leave out something crucial. And this way, as I develop it, you get the same thing that I get. And if it's logical to me, then it's going to be logical to you. It makes sense to me, and it's there in developmental structures. I'm not dumping a whole bunch of stuff on them and dig dense chunks that I had thought of previously and I find that it's better for me not to do a lot of that sort of pre-preparation. The pre-preparation that I do is on a technical level. And as far as plot structure and writing structure, I just do it. I just sit there and by God, I'm going to sit there until I get something. And so it's easier to write the book than face a blank piece of paper for nine hours. This work turned out to be a tetralogy. Is that what you intended when you started it? Or is that just how the publisher broke it down? Okay. I did the first one. And then I realized that I wanted to do some more. And I broadened the structure in my mind to see where it would go. And at the end of the book, you look, and you see, well, is there more book or is there not book? Sometimes you really get the feeling that the book is over, especially in a case if the main character dies, then your book's over. That'll do it every time. But eventually I think that'll be six, although I don't feel that it's particularly unfinished, but I know that I have material for two more, and it's a matter of I'm going to, I think, revert them from ban him, so I have to find another home for them before I even consider the other two. And I've been toying with the idea of doing two more. I sold them in France and Italy. So they're coming out there, And I think they're all out of print at this moment. And either we'll revert them or they'll do another round of solicitors with hopefully less horrible covers than those. And we'll see what we can do. But it should be three and three is really what I'm after was the first three as a group. And the fourth one opens up something else to wish there will be two more. And I don't really want to talk about what happens because it's not quite as much fun. The other two will be a little more serious, in a sense, than the others because the characters have matured and their problems are greater, more difficult, and in a sense, more technical. I stopped there because that was, A, a good place to stop, and, B, because I needed to do a little more homework in those areas. I've done that homework now, and I know where I can take it logically, morally, philosophically. but I really didn't right then. The other problem was if you write one thing too long, you seem to think you're going to wake up there. I didn't want to wake up there. It's a nice place to visit, but I don't want to live there. Certain parts of it might be a nice place to visit. Yeah. Okay, I'm glad I asked that question because when I read it, the Carnelian Thrones seemed to me a lot different, and I didn't know if that was my imagination or... No, it was the start of something else. But it's reasonably complete, I think, as it is. But it's definitely, the form is different and the structure of the book itself is different, the split perspectives and stuff. I mean, it wasn't meant to be just a continuation of the others. Okay, so in a succinct statement then, yes, there will be a couple of sequels to the Cornelian Throne. Really, there will be a couple of that. And the mature characters dealing with the skills that they've gained, I think it's worth a shot. what were you uh overall trying to say in the solicitor series if anything um i was actually trying to come to terms with the fact that logically um and mathematically i couldn't come to terms with uh the incidences of esp that i experienced in my own life and uh some of the more tenuous philosophical intuitions i was having that i I just couldn't state. There's no other way really to state those concepts on one level. The relationship of mind to probability, our connection to time, whether we indeed are co-creators in some sense of the universe in which we're living and we're making a future in the past at once. Sometimes in particle physics, I begin to wonder if the universe isn't just giving us whatever particle we choose to dream up. As soon as we think it up, then it comes into being. because we seem to be going further and further down and every time we go down another level, I mean, the quarks split up into little quarks and it's just, it's endless. And a lot of times you could come up with a good mathematical reason for something, then maybe the universe is convinced and it produces it. I have no idea of whether that's going to turn out to be what it is. But if indeed it is, if the anthropophic principle is anywhere near valid, that it is something like that happening, that we are, in a sense, central to creation, which would be nice. I mean, it's good to me. On another level, I wanted to talk about genetic predispositions. Very bright people have a particular problem with both human relationships and sexuality, and I wanted to talk about that, because no matter how intelligent and logical you are, at a certain point, you have to deal with what is your genetic conditioning, and you really get a snoot full of it in a sex act. A person who is intelligent and monitors what's happening to them as they become aroused really realizes that there is a different and much more primal person inside each of us. And I had at that time begun to despair of nurture having anything to do at all with human behavior, thinking that it was almost everything we do seemed to me at that point to be genetically prompted. What Ed Wilson said, that the urge to creativity might be inextricably linked to the desire to own and dominate. And that's one of the central themes there. I'm rather, I was sort of born post-liberated. I was the guy. I was the oldest child, and I was very intelligent, and I was expected to do all the things that any young man was supposed to do. So I had come to grips with being a post-lucidrated female, and these people were trying to get to where I started out in agony, these women's livers not realizing what they were letting themselves in for. I also wanted to talk about that. One does have to live in a world with males and females and reproduce and be comfortable with the opposite sex, if not with one's own sex. If I had to have a choice with whom I'm comfortable, and as my life has worked out, it's been a real choice. I tend to have a lot of men's friends. And my concerns tend to be mostly those of my work, and that brings me into contact with many more men than women. and the estuary persona is a persona that is in no way less than wholly female while being very intelligent and reasonably comfortable with that balance. It was an injection at that time that I was putting into consciousness to sort of inoculate people against extremes of the female liberation movement. It was that level. And then there was just the fun of the biology telling the story. Okay, the central scientific aspect of it to me was the sorting, the Hesting, which reminded me of a participatory universe, as you've alluded to, that we can sort through the possibilities and pick the one we want. And that seemed to be grounded in some modern physics. Oh, yeah, really? Well, what's the research that we did on it? I managed to pull scores over a year of testing. My average was 100,000 of one against beating the machine. So something was obviously happening. Since I had my laboratory, if it's happening in me, it's certainly happening in everybody else. The only way you can know the universe is through yourself. There was plenty of math to pick it up. the participatory universe concept as far as I then knew did not yet exist as a formulated concept but some precursors had. You can go way back to the animus presocratic thought and get information of that sort of free will working in concert with what would be considered the gods in Zeno stuff. and the math there and what I was feeling about the math there I wanted to do totally in English and that's why I divorced the culture so completely from anything that we might know so that I could bring people to it who had no idea that that was physics who had no idea that it was a scientific basis involved and have an have an experiential reality to just really experience the physics of it and see how they felt about it Because to some degree, I think all of us must have sort of a willing conspiracy to not be aware of the degree to which we're creating what's going on around us. And if that's so, it would be nice that we became aware of it so that we could create things that were a little more to our liking. The... ...we're here to talk about these things in mathematical terms than it is to talk about them. We were here to do the same thing. It sounds like you're pushing God or fate or any one of a number of terms that are highly out of fashion right now, certainly with logical minds. But that's where you end up. If you go all the way to the end of the theoretical physics, you've either got frozen passage, which I don't like, or you've got this, whatever it is. And now we have a word for it, anthropos principled, participatory universe. And it's nice that we have the terminology, but at the time when it's writing notes, the terminology didn't exist just the experience in some people's research and i had read a lot of other people's similar research and if one likes quantum mechanics at all something like that has to be happening you can't have um an arrow of time which goes both ways and not have some kind of print through in order for time to be able to do that you have to be getting some feedback from somewhere so i just put it in there in such a way that they could be comfortable with it And they were so comfortable with it, and it sounded so little like science that three of them came out as fantasy. So he didn't win. I'll make a comment, and then you essentially answered my next question about whether it's fantasy or science fiction. But the first time I ran into a participatory universe in one form, I think, was, you know, you're familiar with the Schroedinger's-Cath paradox. And Eugene Wigner said that maybe a conscious signal makes one of the state vectors collapse one way or the other, and that's kind of interesting. Okay, was it fantasy or science fiction? Because it seemed science fiction to me, but my goodness, it said on the outside, fantasy. All right. And what's the difference? Well, there's a difference. I think it's a conceptual difference. I'm writing pure fantasy in the sanctuary, but it's very historical fantasy. The difference in that particular case was that Frederick Paul, who was my first editor and who knew what was science fiction, left. And the other, I guess, operative difference was that at the point in time when they came out, they could get a bigger print run if they called it fantasy. So it was an editorial difference. rather than a real difference. But those covers did not help me, in the least, get those books to the kind of people that I thought should be reading them. And between that and the fantasy, I didn't realize, because I was never a fan in the sense of someone who was hooked into the community, that there was this great dichotomy and hostility between the science fiction people and the fantasy people and that hardly anyone read both. There was almost no converse between the two. and having an open mind as part of science and dealing with unsolved problems and questions is just as important as showing that you indeed do understand this or that particular principle which seems right now to be valid until next week it turns out that well it just was fudge factor so I don't know if there's a difference for me unfortunately fantasy right now seems to be where the writers so that they don't do any homework and don't really understand either this world or the principles on which fantasy was originally based, the Homeric tradition and a good sense of history and honor and all those nice things that we don't talk about too much anymore. And science fiction is where people write who at least have a willingness to pay some lip service to a logical mind. And fantasy used to be a lot better when most people were writing it. But right now, there's a lot of very mediocre writers writing, you know, good and evil fantasy or warmed-over Christian mythology, which is not, to me, what fantasy is about. I love Conan, you know, original, the Howard stuff and all the real old stuff and Homer and Hesiod. And that, to me, is good fantasy. Science fiction, when it's good, it's great. But the problem exists in science fiction in a different form where the young writers who don't really have a good conceptual basis in science fiction use what I call nuts and bolts, which is just data that they can get from Encyclopedia as their science and have a little trick ending in which some scientific principle is invoked to resolve the plot. But for me, good science fiction has the science as an integral part of the development of the story, and you couldn't have the story without the scientific principle or the theoretical questions that you're basing it on. In other words, if you can take the science out of it and you've still got a story, then you shouldn't have science fiction. It should be something else. TV, something like that. But science fiction should have... almost the science or the theory or the world or whatever you want to call it, the structure that you're making. It adds the central character. And that's what it does. When it does it best, it frees the minds and allows people to come away with lots of good questions that they can think about rather than providing bad answers, which indeed you have a very limited lifespan that we've all seen. Okay, before we leave Solistra, I want to ask a couple of questions about Estri. She starts off as a, what, a courtesan? Is that the proper word? Yeah, I think that was it. The books, well, the first three anyway, to me, were just this continual rite of passage where she gets up to the god class. Does this in any way reflect the way you went through the post-feminism thing or what? Do you make it to the god class? Not yet, huh? Not yet, no. I don't know. The character had to be consistent with what she was, right? The biological nature of the solicitors were such that once I had laid out the structure in the first one, I had to keep it going. But I am not my book. the heroin the female lead in which she is a lead and the dream dancer thing is really polar opposite of Astri I was a sexual athlete from 15 to 19 till I found my mate and then I settled right down but I wasn't trying to give a course in how to do it but I was trying to discuss ways that males and females could relate to each other given the structure where everyone at Solicitor is concerned with genetic goals and their concerns are pretty much replication in power that's what they're concerned with and that is the basis of most human behavior it's just that we spend a lot of time not looking at the degree to which it affects our decision making on on more and more rarified levels it's nice to remember once in a while I like to look back at those books and remember that at one point I was that well grounded in reality that I didn't take it too far to the abstract there and that it stayed pretty much where I put it the character was slow learning in a sense but I think if you consider the lifespans involved with those people everything would have had to have been slowed down because if you You're just, you know, coming into your adulthood at 300. That meant you were probably a child for about 110 years. That's an awful long time for toilet training. So everything was slowed down with them. And I tried to keep the balance that was inherent in the culture. As I say, after a certain point, the story just goes. And I don't want to be an editor to the characters. And when they start telling me what they're going to do, who I had as Sarah's character at one point, I had gone to a lot of trouble to put that character where I thought he should be, doing what I thought he should be doing, and the character got out of story mode and sort of crossed his mental arms and said, well, I wouldn't do that. And we had a discussion, I stopped writing, and I had a sort of a split mental discussion with this character for a couple weeks about what he should want and what he should be. And when that happens, you go with it because you get lucky. That doesn't always happen in the book. Sometimes you really are controlling a great deal of how it resolved and if a character wants to take on a life of his own and discuss it with you I believe it was Dostoevsky said that he was tyrannical with his characters Lee Carey says that he makes deals with them he says well if you'll just stay in the background for this book I'll give you one of your own next time I've done that too I've made deals with characters they just remain small in this book I'll move them over you know give them another life and another world and when you have that you're very lucky I know people never get that and think that the people, I can't risk telling you about this because I know authors who think that writers that speak this way are lying or crazy or both. But it does happen, and when it happens, those of us that it happens too are damn glad to get it. Okay, the engineer says we better flip our tape. Do you want to take a little break or anything while we do it? You're doing great, yes.

segments.text: So the tape is on, and so everything is recorded for posterity.
Okay, turn the tape off just a second.
It is on now, so it is on now.
So I'll start off by asking you a little bit about your background,
specifically how you grew up and what might have influenced you to write
and why science fiction particularly.
Okay.
Okay. I grew up in a very literary family with an influence on technology.
My father restructured the Boeing paperwork stuff at Otis Air Force Base when we had missiles up here in the 50s.
So there was a lot of military people around my house and high tech people, pilots, submarine guys, stuff like that.
So I met a lot of people like this very early on.
and when I was seven, I started reading science fiction,
but before that, my mother was a master's in education,
my father went to Harvard,
and my bedtime story is when I was three and four,
well, I'm a fairy queen.
So I had a, in mythology,
so I had a real good background in not only literature,
but in particular sorts of literature
that ended up translating into science fiction and fantasy later on.
I read fiction voraciously.
I got a hardcover book a week with my allowance when I was in second and third grade.
Being an over-advantaged child in a public school was very difficult for gifted children.
I had really nothing to do in school.
I was finished with the year's reading in October, and I would sit.
They would make me just sit there.
So I did a lot of extracurricular reading.
I think the first story I read was James Blish's Surface Pension,
and I've now dated myself.
I think it was an IF magazine way way back and I read science fiction almost exclusively until
I started reading non-fiction of philosophy about 10 and 11 and then at the same time I went through
the five libraries within driving distances collection of mythology so I had all the myths
of all available countries including Asian and African by then then went into philosophy and
work backwards from the existentialists and Sardin back,
bounced all the way back to pre-Socratic thought
and got into physics from there.
And that got me back to hard science
through the interaction, really,
of philosophy and theoretical physics
in the space-time thing
and later into geopronometry,
which is an area which I really like to play with.
And some of that I think shows in the book.
When in my late 20s I got involved with a physicist who because he was doing some work in quantum mechanics was interested to see if indeed he could come up with some reversibility.
Some evidence that the arrows of time do go both ways.
There should be, if indeed this is true, on some level.
even though your watch won't put itself together
after it's broken on the floor,
fly up and land on your wrist.
There should be some way that we can determine
that time is indeed working both ways.
It's an iteration in math.
To do that, I punched a lot of buttons
because, I mean, I have car dreams,
dreams that come true.
It's really unfortunate for somebody as logical as I am
to be slapped in the face with precognitive dreams
and incidences of ESP.
So then I went into studying that a little bit.
And we did a bunch of computer work, really, testing against probability
to see if indeed mine could be demonstrated to be affecting probability
in a randomly generated sequence of numbers.
And after about a year working on that,
we proved our satisfaction that something was happening,
and it seemed to be happening most strongly and most consistently
in people who were in some way or form connected with nonverbal arts.
Musicians, artists, people who paint as opposed to all sorts of artists.
But people who are not logically tied down in some way to semantics.
Later on, we went and tried, on the basis of that, research to get a National Science Foundation grant to study it.
But it was right about the time they were trying to throw the parapsychologist out of the National Science Foundation.
Consequently, we did not get the grant and didn't carry it on any further.
Does that answer your question?
That's a good start.
Okay.
You have this remarkable background then in reading all sorts of philosophy and that sort of thing
and you are interested in science.
Are you a logical kind of left hemisphere person?
Yeah, most determinedly.
The other stuff bothers me very much.
Because I like to be able to figure things out,
and because most things fall to logic in the end,
the things that are illogical tend to be what I concentrate on.
Because after one solves what's solvable,
what remains the question?
The things that one can't determine.
And that throws you back to the nature, really, of time
and what consciousness is.
the role of the observer
in not only the modern world,
but maybe in the actual creation
of what we see
as the rational and physical world around us.
So that's what I'm working with,
struggling to deal with,
maybe, in the fiction.
Okay.
This is, as an aside,
but as I mentioned on the phone the other night,
I make my living as a scientist,
but as a layman,
I'm very interested in cosmology
and quantum mechanics
and that sort of thing.
So I think that's probably why
your writing appeals to me so much because you
investigate some of these things that I can't
verbalize nearly as well
as another site is a book
that you might be familiar with
From Being to Becoming by
Ilya Prigogini I think you pronounce it
yes that's how you pronounce it he's one of my
heroes have you seen that book
I have
seen the book I do not have a copy
of it
his area is really your area
chemistry and thermodynamics and he's
dealing in that book
with the kind of questions that also interests you,
I think it would be nice for you to take a look at.
Okay, I appreciate the suggestion.
He won the Nobel in, I think, 77, yeah.
Plus he comes to Austin.
He's part-time at UT Austin, too, so it's not that far away.
In it, he's really coming to terms with the same kinds of problems.
I mean, are there determinable instances?
Is it one flow of time?
Why, indeed, isn't this happening?
Why don't we see reversibility in nature?
And almost calling for a restructure of the questions, which is nice.
Very bright, very bright, darn.
Oh, yeah, of course.
His main bag is non-equilibrium thermodynamics, where you get,
oh, I guess there's a big argument that the creationists can throw up
that life cannot have evolved spontaneously
because entropy makes it go the other way.
you tend towards disorder, and he has refuted that quite nicely.
I've read quite a few of those papers.
So, okay, I guess I ought to stick to them.
Let's see.
Well, part of my kick in this is this kind of stuff.
Of course, the author on the other end might not want to stay forever, so.
I don't mind it.
Wheeler, too, you would like.
Oh, yeah, I'm very familiar.
I've read a lot of his stuff.
I really like that.
The universe ordered itself as it did in the initial instance
in order to produce physicists.
I think it's just wonderful.
Yeah.
Let's see, who is it?
The anthropomorphic principle.
Prophecy principle, right.
Yeah, right.
That's quite interesting.
And then the many worlds.
One more clue, let's see.
The DeWitt model, it's called the many worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics.
It's quite interesting.
You are probably familiar with it.
Yeah, I was thinking of fooling around with that next time.
It's just awful hard to use a structure like that in a book
because it's going to not look like a novel.
It's going to look like lots of parts of a novel.
Right, especially since quantum mechanics says that the many worlds
could not communicate amongst each other,
but maybe you can find a way to get around that,
and then it would be quite interesting.
We would be writing really parallel structures,
but it would be fun to do.
That's what I think science fiction should do,
is deal with the new concepts rather than just older, rehashed science fictional concepts
because the really creative stuff is starting to happen now
because people are asking much more interesting questions than scientists' level.
In the Patchen Review article, the second one where you signed your name,
you talked about scientific speculation and that perhaps it's not...
that even the science fiction writers
have grown conservative
about speculating about science.
That was written a couple of years ago.
I guess, do you still feel
pretty strongly about that?
Yeah, I'm afraid that I do.
Because if not,
because of the way I work
and the amount of concentration
and area it takes,
I mean, right now,
I just got finished with mycotoxins
and the whole Afghanistan thing,
biochemical warfare,
and surveillance stuff.
So I've been reading, that's what I've been reading
for the last year, really
the technology that is here now
in depth.
So if somebody, what happens is
the fiction reading stuff is what I don't get
to read when I'm
researching a subject is what other
people are writing because it's so peripheral
to what I'm doing. So if somebody in the last
couple years has come along
in science fiction who's taking risks
and taking shots and using
the new data
that's coming in,
then I don't know about it.
But,
as of two years ago,
when I was really
conversant with
who was writing
and what they were writing,
it seemed to me that
they were almost ignorant
of anything
that one would consider
an advance
in the theory of science
that had happened
in the last 20 years.
And I think that's
really a shame
because that's what
science fiction
is supposed to do.
We have a brighter audience.
They're at an age
where they're deciding
what they're going to do
a lot of the time for a living.
They're comfortable with technology
and they're adventurous.
And to not give a questioning mind
something interesting to chew on,
which is what I found was nice
about science fiction
when I first started reading it,
is a shame.
To some extent,
the problem is in the editor's publishers,
but they can't buy a better book
than you send them.
So if people are sending them garbage,
which then garbage is all they can buy.
I mean garbage from a conceptual point of view,
there's plenty of people in science fiction that can write,
but there's very few of them that are writing about anything interesting.
And what I try to do always is to put in,
if not leading edge stuff, new stuff,
make the hard stuff simple,
at least science that is still viable as a speculation.
I really like Twisters.
I just love Ken Rose and the whole Twister Theory thing.
That makes great sense to me.
And I wanted to give people some exposure to it.
But there's always a new thought.
There's a new permutation.
Something more interesting.
I was complaining in that about tachyons,
because I think tachyons are a dead issue.
And considering, especially the source,
that the writer, who is certainly aware of more modern
and interesting concepts than tachyons,
could have done better.

And if the best of the writers that we have, in the sense of the most technologically literate, aren't going to do it, then nobody's going to do it and the level will go down and down, as it's been going down in all fiction. It's a conservative market. They want to buy what they can sell. They're absolutely sure that everybody that buys these books is eight years old, and I know that they're not. So I write for my ideal audience, which is intelligent and adventurous.
okay I think what I'm going to do now
okay I'll go back up to
and we'll start on Solistra
this is
yes oh yes
great
I keep debating if I start backwards

it'll be easier
okay reportedly
or it says in the back of the first Solistra book

So how did you go from writing one short story
to a very successful science fantasy novel?
Okay.
Actually, I didn't even write it beforehand.
I wrote this tiny short story called An Antidreaming,
and I wrote it between, I guess,
between Wind from the Abyss and the Golden Sword
just to peg the idea and open the door so I can get back into that thing that I saw.
I tend to see a story, the concepts are one thing.
You put the concepts in and they gestate,
and then I don't have to look around for a story.
I mean, I see characters.
I don't sit down there to write until I see something.
And it's almost like you're looking into a telescope
and the story is at the other end,
so there's a degree of automatic writing in it.
But I always knew I was going to write.
you know
you win a poetry contest
in first grade
and you always get an A
on the essay question
there are certain signs
I don't think you can learn
to write
I think you're either
a writer or you're not
you can learn to be an author
someone who writes
just enough to be able
to go around
and talk about their books
and be a big shot
or a literary snob
but a person who likes
is willing to sit in a room
and spend most of their time
in a non-existent world
and make very good friends
with a typewriter
or a word processor
That's something that you have to be born
with the drive and the obsession to do.
I did a lot of life research
before I sat down to write anything
because I felt that you have to have something to say.
And having survived my research,
when we moved to a quiet place
and I actually had the time
and I found that I did have a specific idea,
I sat down and wrote to Lister
And I didn't do any warm-up.
That is the first thing I ever wrote for sale.
And it's also the first draft of the first thing I ever wrote.
It never occurred to me that a story could go any way but the original way.
So I wrote it and I typed it up and it sat around for a year
because I didn't know where to send it.
And then I sent it out.
And the agent said, well, you know, he thought he could sell it.
And I said, fine, because I wrote two more in the meantime.
And indeed he did sell them.
So I did no warm-up.
But I did wait.
I didn't try until I knew I could do it.
not a big one for preparation.
The only preparation I think you can do for writing is reading.
And over the years I've done plenty of reading,
but the other thing you should need to do
if you're going to write about the stuff of life,
the human element is to experience some of the human element.
And I spent quite a bit of time in New York and underground
and doing dangerous, dicey things.
And every time something would be exceedingly difficult,
like when I was looking down the wrong end of the gun
or tied up in my apartment in New York by a hostile forest,
I would think, well, I can use this in my book.
And it got me through a lot of very difficult situations,
just thinking that if I could just get through this,
eventually I was going to have plenty of material for a book.
And what I ended up doing was writing for a living.
you uh wrote using a first person point of view except for a couple of
delcretz sequences in the carnelian throne and it's kind of hard to write first person how did
you decide to do that i think it was in that case it was easier but with phyllistha um
there's a one has to be a little bit messianic to do a book like that i really was
concerned that when I got
into the very
abstract stuff
that I
must have some way to take them with
me. I wanted them to experience
this stuff as closely
and as possible
because of the kinds of things
that I was talking about, both the philosophical things
and the genetic
experience that
I wanted to give them.
The sufficient characters are almost like walking
genes. At the time I was quite taken with Edmund Wilson in sociobiology. I still think
some of the things that are valid although they've spun it out past the point where I
can agree with them now. So first person was the way to go with that book. As I said I
see a story. I don't have to manufacture the story. Once I have a character or a group
of characters I can just let it go. By then the work is done and I just write it and I
write it in deep immersion and
stay home a lot and don't cook dinner.
The cats scream at me.
So first-person
for that was easier to get
you really inside the characters and
prepared for things like
the multiple world stuff that
came at the end of that first book
later on. And it was a little bit
more of a discipline
to write first-person because
one doesn't do it in essay class, certainly
not in college.
It just was the
way that book wanted to be written.
I don't tend to pay
too much attention
to the style
that I'm writing because
I want to make the style fit the piece.
So the style
develops itself in accordance
with the concepts that I want to work
with. Sometimes I'll
get a very dense style
like
in
Earth Dreams was
dense.
because the concepts were difficult.
I knew where I was going to deal
with those concepts.
I needed a style where
when I started talking,
technically,
it wouldn't be too great a jerk,
too different
from the stuff that was going on
before it.
Also, there I was trying to blend
the pure logic of hard science
with the absolute
other side of the brain,
ill logic of magic,
and I needed a way to do it.
So the styles develop
out of that.
And each group of things I do
tends to be very different stylistically from the last.
Solicitor is very different from the carrying stuff,
which is very different from the sanctuary stuff,
which is different.
I did a historical with Cal Watkins at Harvard
and a Hittite king, which I sold
and then reverted him in the process of selling again.
And in that book, we had translated stuff
that had never been seen in English before,
Acadian, and lots of old Hittite.
And that style was determined by the fact that I knew I was going to be using big chunks of text
and I wanted to use it as it transliterated rather than modernizing the translation.
So that again was first person because all the text we had was first person.
So I let the story determine the style rather.
I don't really choose it.
A lot of times I don't think I choose the stories either.
When I'm on the rebound from the amount of hard mathematical homework that I do,
I tell myself if the story takes me
because otherwise why should I have to work so hard?
Okay.
The set,
the Solicitor, The Planet,
it's exceedingly complex.
You've got all these relationships,
you've got all these politics,
inter-world politics,
intra-world politics,
you've got a lot of jargon,
at the end you have a dictionary.
Leigh Killough said when she writes books,
she writes a world book,
just describing everything about the world
which is often longer than the novel that she writes from it.
Did you lay down this world in your head and think it through,
or did this just come to you as you were writing it, because it's so damn complex?
Okay, I have a very good memory, an edific memory.
I can remember everything that I do.
And I can also remember most of what I read, you know, page number and how it looks on the page.
the glossary and the dictionary and the end paper matter all that stuff was done after
high touch was sold at the publisher's request i didn't have that in the original manuscript at
all what i had and what i always have is um a manila folder that i keep the manuscript in
and where i jot down notes as to what i have done so in other words as i as i made up the words
the language i'd write down the new words on the manila envelope i don't like to take
a lot of notes because i'll lose them and i just keep it all in my head and i better be damn sure
that i remember what's in there so i'm very careful about that but no i don't do anything
like that as i tell you it's a very the actual writing for me is a very visceral experience
so much as something you know sometimes under your pseudonym i do uh and now time stuff you
know hear stuff's in there i mean if i have to stop to get an air and a sectional you know an
air map of a particular place to find out what the route would be then that'll pull me out of it or
you know how much it costs a particular hotel or what kind of ammunition would be right for this
gun or that gun then i have to stop and go and get the data but where it's all made up all i have to
do is be consistent with myself and logical within the frame so i keep it in my head where it belongs
That way I find if I write a lot of stuff first,
then I find that I'm in danger of not explaining it well enough to the reader
because I already know it so well that I might leave out something crucial.
And this way, as I develop it, you get the same thing that I get.
And if it's logical to me, then it's going to be logical to you.
It makes sense to me, and it's there in developmental structures.
I'm not dumping a whole bunch of stuff on them
and dig dense chunks that I had thought of previously
and I find that it's better for me
not to do a lot of that sort of pre-preparation.
The pre-preparation that I do is on a technical level.
And as far as plot structure and writing structure,
I just do it.
I just sit there and by God,
I'm going to sit there until I get something.
And so it's easier to write the book
than face a blank piece of paper for nine hours.
This work turned out to be a tetralogy.
Is that what you intended when you started it?
Or is that just how the publisher broke it down?
Okay.
I did the first one.
And then I realized that I wanted to do some more.
And I broadened the structure in my mind
to see where it would go.
And at the end of the book, you look,
and you see, well, is there more book
or is there not book?
Sometimes you really get the feeling
that the book is over,
especially in a case if the main character dies, then your book's over.
That'll do it every time.
But eventually I think that'll be six,
although I don't feel that it's particularly unfinished,
but I know that I have material for two more,
and it's a matter of I'm going to, I think, revert them from ban him,
so I have to find another home for them before I even consider the other two.
And I've been toying with the idea of doing two more.
I sold them in France and Italy.
So they're coming out there,
And I think they're all out of print at this moment.
And either we'll revert them or they'll do another round of solicitors
with hopefully less horrible covers than those.
And we'll see what we can do.
But it should be three and three is really what I'm after
was the first three as a group.
And the fourth one opens up something else
to wish there will be two more.
And I don't really want to talk about what happens
because it's not quite as much fun.
The other two will be a little more serious, in a sense,
than the others because the characters have matured
and their problems are greater, more difficult,
and in a sense, more technical.
I stopped there because that was, A, a good place to stop,
and, B, because I needed to do a little more homework in those areas.
I've done that homework now, and I know where I can take it logically,
morally, philosophically.
but I really didn't right then.
The other problem was if you write one thing too long,
you seem to think you're going to wake up there.
I didn't want to wake up there.
It's a nice place to visit, but I don't want to live there.
Certain parts of it might be a nice place to visit.
Yeah.
Okay, I'm glad I asked that question because when I read it,
the Carnelian Thrones seemed to me a lot different,
and I didn't know if that was my imagination or...
No, it was the start of something else.
But it's reasonably complete, I think, as it is.
But it's definitely, the form is different
and the structure of the book itself is different,
the split perspectives and stuff.
I mean, it wasn't meant to be just a continuation of the others.
Okay, so in a succinct statement then,
yes, there will be a couple of sequels to the Cornelian Throne.
Really, there will be a couple of that.
And the mature characters dealing with the skills that they've gained,
I think it's worth a shot.
what were you uh overall trying to say in the solicitor series if anything
um i was actually trying to come to terms with the fact that logically
um and mathematically i couldn't come to terms with uh the incidences of esp that i experienced
in my own life and uh some of the more tenuous philosophical intuitions i was having that i
I just couldn't state.
There's no other way really to state those concepts on one level.
The relationship of mind to probability, our connection to time,
whether we indeed are co-creators in some sense of the universe in which we're living
and we're making a future in the past at once.
Sometimes in particle physics, I begin to wonder if the universe isn't just giving us
whatever particle we choose to dream up.
As soon as we think it up, then it comes into being.
because we seem to be going further and further down
and every time we go down another level,
I mean, the quarks split up into little quarks
and it's just, it's endless.
And a lot of times you could come up
with a good mathematical reason for something,
then maybe the universe is convinced
and it produces it.
I have no idea of whether that's going to turn out
to be what it is.
But if indeed it is,
if the anthropophic principle is anywhere near valid,
that it is something like that happening,
that we are, in a sense, central to creation,
which would be nice.
I mean, it's good to me.
On another level, I wanted to talk about genetic predispositions.
Very bright people have a particular problem
with both human relationships and sexuality,
and I wanted to talk about that,
because no matter how intelligent and logical you are,
at a certain point, you have to deal with
what is your genetic conditioning,
and you really get a snoot full of it in a sex act.
A person who is intelligent and monitors what's happening to them
as they become aroused really realizes that there is a different
and much more primal person inside each of us.
And I had at that time begun to despair of nurture having anything to do at all
with human behavior, thinking that it was almost everything we do
seemed to me at that point to be genetically prompted.
What Ed Wilson said, that the urge to creativity
might be inextricably linked to the desire to own and dominate.
And that's one of the central themes there.
I'm rather, I was sort of born post-liberated.
I was the guy.
I was the oldest child, and I was very intelligent,
and I was expected to do all the things that any young man was supposed to do.
So I had come to grips with being a post-lucidrated female,
and these people were trying to get to where I started out in agony,
these women's livers not realizing what they were letting themselves in for.
I also wanted to talk about that.
One does have to live in a world with males and females and reproduce
and be comfortable with the opposite sex, if not with one's own sex.
If I had to have a choice with whom I'm comfortable,
and as my life has worked out, it's been a real choice.
I tend to have a lot of men's friends.
And my concerns tend to be mostly those of my work,
and that brings me into contact with many more men than women.
and the estuary persona is a persona that is in no way less than wholly female
